introduction.p:
Consider a function that is piecewise-defined according to the formula
f(x) = \begin{cases}3(x+2)+2 \amp \text{ for }-3 \lt x \lt -2 \\ \frac{2}{3}(x+2)+1 \amp \text{ for }-2 \le x \lt -1 \\ \frac{2}{3}(x+2)+1 \amp \text{ for }-1 \lt x \lt 1 \\ 2 \amp \text{ for }x = 1 \\ 4-x \amp \text{ for }x \gt 1 \end{cases}
Use the given formula to answer the following questions.

figure.caption: Axes for plotting the function y = f(x) in Activity.

statement.p: For each of the values a = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, compute f(a).

hint.p: Find the interval in which a lies and evaluate the function there.

statement.p: For each of the values a = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, determine \lim_{x \to a^-} f(x) and \lim_{x \to a^+} f(x).

hint.p: Remember that for \lim_{x \to a^-} f(x), we only consider values of x such that x \lt a. Find the right formula to use in the piecewise definition for f to fit the values you are considering.

statement.p: For each of the values a = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, determine \lim_{x \to a} f(x). If the limit fails to exist, explain why by discussing the left- and right-hand limits at the relevant a-value.

hint.p: Use your work in (c) and compare left- and right-hand limits.

answer.p: \lim_{x \to -2} f(x) does not exist. The values of the limits as x \to a for a = -1, 0, 1, 2 are \frac{5}{3}, \frac{7}{3}, 3, 2.

solution.p: \lim_{x \to -2} f(x) does not exists because the left-hand limit is 2 while the right-hand limit is 1. All of the other requested limits exist, as left- and right-hand limits exist and are equal in each case. The respective values of the limits as x \to a for a = -1, 0, 1, 2 are \frac{5}{3}, \frac{7}{3}, 3, 2.

statement.p:
For which values of a is the following statement true?
\lim_{x \to a} f(x) \ne f(a)

solution.p: For a = -2, a = -1, and a = 1, \lim_{x \to a} f(x) \ne f(a). At a = -2, the limit fails to exist, but f(-2) = 1. At a = -1, the limit is \frac{5}{3}, but f(-1) is not defined. At a = 1, the limit is 3, but f(1) = 2.

statement.p: On the axes provided in Figure, sketch an accurate, labeled graph of y = f(x). Be sure to carefully use open circles (○) and filled circles (●) to represent key points on the graph, as dictated by the piecewise formula.

hint.p: Note that f is piecewise linear.
